pages.text: The MIDI Input Device Configuration GUI allows you to get a list of MIDI devices currently available on your system and select the one to use for the MIMI System MIDI Input Device on your instruments.$(br2)Note that changes to your selected device require a game restart to take affect.

pages.title: Accessing the GUI
pages.text: You can access the MIDI Input Device Configuration GUI by pressing the configured Keybind at any time while loaded into a world.$(br2)The current keybind is: $(l)$(k:key.mimi.midi.settings)$()

pages.title: Physical MIDI Devices
pages.text: In order to play MIDI data in MIMI you must have at least one compatible MIDI device available on your system.$(br2)If you have a physical MIDI-enabled device (like a digital piano) that should work with a USB to MIDI adapter as long as your system is able to recognize it. For help with connecting a MIDI device to your system see $(l:https://www.musicrepo.com/how-to-connect-midi-keyboard-to-computer/)here$(/l).

pages.title: Loopback Devices
pages.text: You can also use any MIDI output available on your system as MIDI input into MIMI via a Loopback Device.$(br2)A loopback device is essentially a device that takes a MIDI output and re-broadcasts it as a MIDI input to be used in another MIDI device. This could be used to use an installed MIDI player program as a MIDI device in MIMI.

pages.title: Loopback Devices
pages.text: Setting up MIDI loopback varies based on your operating system. Here are some links to get you started:$(br2)$(l)Windows$() - $(l:https://www.tobias-erichsen.de/software/loopmidi.html)loopMIDI$(/l)$(br2)$(l)Mac$() - $(l:https://help.ableton.com/hc/en-us/articles/209774225-Setting-up-a-virtual-MIDI-bus#Mac)Built-in IAC$(/l)$(br2)$(l)Linux$() - This depends on your distribution and some don't play nice with Java. One popular option is $(l:https://jackaudio.org/)JACK$(/l).
